musicalLanguage.description: A hard-swinging blues-jazz riff tune popularized by Oscar Peterson. Built on a simple, infectious riff over a 12-bar blues form, Night Train is pure energy and groove. The left hand drives with a walking bass feel while the right hand punches out the iconic riff pattern.
musicalLanguage.structure: 12-bar blues riff form. This excerpt: first 8 bars (I and IV)
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: The main riff — punchy, rhythmic, impossible not to tap your foot
Bar 5-6: Riff transposes to the IV chord (C7) — same energy, new pitch
Bar 7-8: Return to G7 with the riff building momentum
teachingGoals: Riff-based playing — repeat a short phrase with conviction
Walking bass in the left hand — steady quarter note motion
Blues-jazz crossover style — harder swing than cool jazz
styleTips: Swing HARD — this is Oscar Peterson, not a ballad. Dig in.
The riff should be short and punchy — staccato quarter notes
Left hand walks confidently — each note leading to the next

measures.teachingNote: G7 — the main riff begins. Short, punchy notes. Left hand walks up.
G7 continues. The riff adds the b7 (F5) for blues flavor. Left hand walks back down.
Riff repeats — build confidence through repetition. Same energy.
G7 — last bar before the IV chord. Left hand walks down to A2, approaching C.
C7 — the riff transposes up to the IV chord. Same shape, new key center!
C7 continues. Bb is the b7 of C. Left hand walks back down.
Back to G7 — home riff returns. Feels like an arrival.
G7 — the riff compresses to eighth notes then rests. Building anticipation for the V chord.
